questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of fever and painful burning lesions on his right knee. Which of the following is not indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A systemic response(fever), along with prodromal symptoms like pain and presence of grouped herpetiform vesicles developing on the erythematous base is classical of Herpes zoster infection. In this case fluconazole is not indicated.

Tricyclic antidepressants are given for the management of pain.

Glucocorticoids are given for reduction of inflammation. However, it should not be used without concomitant antiviral therapy.

questions.text: A score of 3 for motor response according to the Glasgow Coma Scale indicates _________.
questions.solution:
Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup.  On examination size of the uterus corresponds to 26 weeks of gestation and the fetal heart rate is 130 beats/min.  The amniotic fluid index is 4 in the sonogram.  Which of the following fetal anomalies is likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of oligohydramnios and it can be associated with renal agenesis. 

Maternal causes Fetal causes Placental causes
Post-dated pregnancy Fetal anomalies  Placental insufficiency
Pre-eclampsia  Renal agenesis, urethral defects (posterior valve, obstructive uropathy) Failure of secretion: Amnion Nodosum
NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors     

Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)

Spontaneous rupture of membranes

    

Related Pearl: Causes of oligo and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal

Post-dated pregnancy, Pre- Eclampsia, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)

Spontaneous rupture of membranes

Diabetes, cardiac & renal diseases, liver failure

Fetal

Fetal anomalies, Renal agenesis, urethral defects (posterior valve, obstructive uropathy)

 

Neural tube defects, open spina bifida, anencephaly, abdominal wall defects, cleft palate, neck masses, aneuploidy, hydrops fetalis, twin to twin transfusion syndrome, multiple pregnancies 

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion Nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: The milestone shown in the image is attained by the age of _______
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. In case of a mature pincer grasp, the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text:
On chest X-ray PA view, right cardiac border is formed by_________
1. SVC
2. IVC 
3. Right atrium 
4. Right ventricle
questions.solution:
On a chest X-ray PA view,

Right cardiac border formed by:

  • SVC
  • Right atrium
  • IVC

Left cardiac border formed by:

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knuckle
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a hypopigmented patch on her face with fine scaling. There is a history of atopy in the family.  What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of age, fine scaling, distribution of the lesions and history of atopy suggests the diagnosis pityriasis alba.

  • Pityriasis Alba is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature.
  • It is seen in the age group of 3 to 16 years.
  • The individual lesion is a rounded oval or irregular hypopigmented patch, which is usually not well marginated.
  • Lesions have scaling.
  • In children, the lesions are often confined to the face and are most common on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin.
  • Pityriasis alba is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.

Other Options:

Leprosy: The hypopigmented patch is often associated with atrophy, loss of sensation and loss of sweating. The lesion is not scaly.

Pityriasis Versicolor: The hypopigmented macules are perifollicular in distribution. Fine, powdery branny scaling is present. Scratch sign positive. No relation to atopy.

Atopic eczema: Characteristic itchy papules will be present, hypopigmentation is not a feature.

The given image shows Bohler Braun splint used for unilateral leg traction.

  • The proximal pulley is used to prevent foot drop.
  • The 2nd pulley is used for traction in line with the hip.
  • The 3rd pulley is used for traction in line with foot.

Other options:

Option A: Thomas splint is used for tibial fractures.

Parts of Thomas splint

  • Outer bar
  • Inner bar
  • Ring

The outer bar has a curvature near its junction to ring to accommodate greater trochanter.

Option B: The image shows a foot abduction orthosis called Dennin Browne splint which is used for correction of CTEV and club foot. 

Option D: Cock up splint is a wrist hand orthosis used for radial nerve palsy. 

Related Pearl: Commonly used splints and their indications

questions.text: The facial nerve divides into 2 main terminal trunks. One is cervicofacial. The other is______
questions.solution:
• The extratemporal course of facial nerve starts at the Stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone.
  • It runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland.
  • Here it divides into 2 main terminal trunks:
    • Temporofacial and
    • Cervicofacial.
  • These further divide and re-anastomose in varied patterns to give the terminal branches:
    • Temporal
    • Zygomatic
    • Buccal
    • Mandibular
    • Cervical

questions.text: A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Removing the lens as a whole is the best treatment option. If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole.

For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

  • The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.
  • If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.
  • If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

Waste sharps are disposed by mutilation and shredding.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique.
questions.solution:
The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

questions.text: α1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme ________.
questions.solution:
α1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

  • Lysosomal enzymes, if unchecked, can potentiate further inflammation by damaging tissues.
  • These harmful proteases, however, are normally controlled by a system of antiproteases in the serum and tissue fluids.
  • α1-antitrypsin is the prototype member of the serine protease inhibitor (serpin) superfamily of proteins.

Clinical correlate:

  • Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency (α1-ATD) is caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene located in the long arm of chromosome 14.
  • This genetic defect alters the configuration of the α1-antitrypsin molecule and prevents its release from hepatocytes.
  • As a result, serum levels of α1-antitrypsin are decreased, leading to low alveolar concentrations, where the α1-antitrypsin molecule normally would provide protection against proteases such neutrophil elastase.
  • The resulting protease excess in alveoli destroys alveolar walls and causes emphysema.

questions.text: After administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nausea and vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness in the tip of the finger that eventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated in the above findings?
questions.solution:
Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of dihydroergotamine.

The numbness progressing to bluish discoloration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. This is a rare adverse effect of dihydroergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of
questions.solution:
Inferior pancreatico-duodenal artery is a branch of superior mesenteric artery.

On the other hand, the superior pancreatico-duodenal artery is a branch of the gastroduodenal artery. 

 

The main vessels supplying the duodenum are superior and inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.solution:
In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next cell.

The transmis­sion in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlike chemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity.

Note:  

Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system are chemical synapses.

Related Pearl: Differences between Chemical and Electrical Synapses

Property

Chemical Synapse

Electrical Synapse

Distance between pre- and post-synaptic membranes

20-40 nm

4nm

Cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and post-synaptic cells

No

Yes

Ultrastructural components

Presynaptic vesicles and active zones; post synaptic receptors

Gap junctions

Agents of transmission

Chemical transmitter

Ion current

Synaptic delay

Significant: atleast 0.3 ms, usually 1-5 ms or longer

Virtually absent

Direction of transmission

Unidirectional

Usually bidirectional
